Stefan asks a question that Emma already answered. "Feminism by definition 
means equal rights and opportunities for both sexes". No need to 
facetiously speculate of what that "feminist harry potter girl" might have 
meant.
Don't be a dick. The rant is full of straw man fallacies.﻿

+Dave XB Oh boy... ok I'll try to explain. Take this for example:

"Also you seem to not understand what a strawman argument is. You certainly 
haven't explained how refusing to allow the child victim of rape any rights 
and in fact further victimizing him, because he is male, is a strawman 
argument."

What an amazing feat! I expressively wrote that I do not dispute your more 
or less hypothetical extreme cases. Then you CONTINUE to fail to grasp that 
further arguing as if I would hold these extreme (and obviously unethical) 
point of views is a straw man argument. You attack me on a position that is 
not mine WHILE trying to tell me I don't know what a strawman logical 
fallacy is. Double think much? I think so. Or maybe just an amazing feat of 
trollery.

And yes I feel free to insult you because it is useless to try to discuss 
rationally with people who are unable to think rationally.

You try to impose simplistic rules on complex problems and that makes you 
are a fanatic and unable to learn from discourse. Regardless what anybody 
says you will continue to see what you want to see, hear what you want to 
hear, and never will be able to look past your preconceptions and 
ideology. You might change those when you stumble upon another narcissistic 
type person you can worship but the underlying pattern of ideology will 
stay the same.

+Dejay Rezme Do you realise that you just wrote: "You probably don't 
realize this but you are simply too stupid / uneducated to understand how 
to discuss something."?

Er.... You realise the irony of what you just wrote don't you? You realise 
that you simply threw out a personal insult and did not discuss the topic 
at all. While at the same time accusing me of the very thing your post 
illustrates. You do realise that don't you? 

How old are you? I only ask because if you are a teenager, you should say 
so. Otherwise people are going to evaluate your intellect assuming that you 
are an adult. 

Also you seem to not understand what a strawman argument is. You certainly 
haven't explained how refusing to allow the child victim of rape any rights 
and in fact further victimizing him, because he is male, is a strawman 
argument. This case or example, very clearly demonstrates the flaws in your 
point of view and the flaws in the contemporary legal situation. It strikes 
at precisely the point of the discussion.  

Also you seem to have failed to grasp that you have been illustrating 
exactly my point for me. As a feminist you are opposed to equal rights for 
men and women. We understand that. We get it. You have made your point very 
clear. That is exactly my point also. 

This is why I enjoy your comments. Rather than me simply making claims, 
people can also read your comments to see an illustration of exactly what I 
am talking about. 

Thank you.

+Dave XB Again strawman. You probably don't realize this but you are simply 
too stupid / uneducated to understand how to discuss something.

+Dejay Rezme I have a daughter. 
I am not moving the goal posts. I am using examples to point out the flaws 
in your intractable position. You keep trying to avoid discussing the topic 
by making personal attacks on me. Your attacks simply highlight how little 
you understand this topic. You clearly can't move beyond the one scenario 
and one ideology that paints women as helpless victims. We heard it all 
before. We're not buying it anymore.

+Dejay Rezme I don't place the responsibility on feminism to fight for 
those issues. I agree feminism is not concerned about issues that men face 
at all. Since this isn't actually comparable to the black rights movement 
because both sides have legitimate issues that need addressing, this shows 
that the Men's Rights Movement is as necessary as feminism is. It seems 
that you agree on that point.

+Dave XB Again you are going to extreme cases. That is moving the goal 
post. I'm not arguing against extreme cases like rape. Your initial claim 
was that feminists like Emma Watson are against male reproductive rights.

You claim that men do not have responsibility because women have the 
ability to abort a child. This is not in the interest of society, therefor 
laws don't focus on "men's rights" because reproduction of the species is 
more important that men wanting to fuck and run. Maybe if you had a 
daughter you would understand. They do have shared responsibility the 
minute they CHOOSE to sleep with a women.

If you want to argue you should use rational arguments, without wild leaps 
in logic. You can't claim "men have no choice" they obviously do have 
(except in the extreme case of male rape). You are arguing like a spoiled 
child but you fail to see that this is not a simple matter. There are 3 
parties involved in this whole "male rights" debate. And you are only 
arguing for one of those 3 sides and are not even using logic.

+Dejay Rezme that logic is why child victims of rape have to pay child 
support and it is wrong. You want men to have responsibility without 
chioces or rights. This is 2015. Having sex does not equate to having to 
raise a child. There are many options and choices women can take after sex 
to prevent raising a child. You want men to have all the responsibility 
with no chioces and no rights. That is because you are a feminist. 

You wrote 'ensuring the reproduction of the species is one of the primary 
functions of government'. That is eugenetics. It might have escaped your 
attention that species have reproduced for 2 billion years. People 
reproduce with or without government and no one but you is proposing that 
is 'a primary function of government'.

+Dave XB "Yes having sex is a lifestyle choice. It doesn't imply consent to 
raise a child."

It's not about consent but about responsibility. It's simply what can 
happen when you have sex. If you have sex you have a responsibility if that 
sex results in a child.

And lol eugenics. That's another straw man buddy because you are again 
putting words in my mouth. I was talking about the laws (e.g. child 
support) surrounding reproduction.

+Dejay Rezme ensuring reproduction of the species is not a function of the 
government. You want the government to decide who when and how people will 
reproduce? That's eugenetics. Typical feminist. You want the government to 
determine every aspect of people's lives as long as it's in accordance with 
your ideology.

+Dejay Rezme feminists and feminist organisations fight against men having 
reproductive rights and other rights such as equality in divorce and 
custody.
You want to claim that not every feminist is blocking these rights. You 
want to claim that there are completely invisible silent feminists that are 
truly wanting equal opportunities in all areas. Well these invisible silent 
feminists that you claim exist are of no consequence. 
Yes having sex is a lifestyle choice. It doesn't imply consent to raise a 
child.

+Dave XB +geld213 While all those issues are certainly important why do you 
put the onus or responsibility to fight for those issues on feminism?

Just because feminism doesn't fight for your rights doesn't mean they are 
opposed to them. It doesn't invalidate any other issues feminism presses.

That's like saying "oh the black rights movement don't fight against 
antisemitism therefor they are antisemitic".

I believe this is a "straw man" fallacy, a logical fallacy while arguing. 
You claim your opponent is holding a specific position ("all feminist fight 
against male reproductive rights") while they don't. Emma Watson in her 
speech certainly didn't make any allusions towards that. And just because 
there are crazy feminists doesn't mean that feminism as a cause is misandry.

> "Feminism is about equal rights only for women"
Equal rights ONLY for women or equal rights ONLY for men is the same 
because equality implies, well, equality. If a = b and b = c then a = c.

> "Having a child is a lifestyle choice." 
Fine, then so is having sex. If a man is having sex with women that is his 
lifestyle choice.

And from the perspective of government / law ensuring the reproduction of 
the species is one of the primary functions. Ultimately the welfare of 
children override all ethical considerations of the parents. After all it 
was their lifestyle choice.

+Dejay Rezme "Show me a black rights organisation that advocates for the

+Dave XB "It's very simple once you start to consider women as fully grown 
adults how can take responsibility for their own lifestyle choices."

You talk about hypocrisy but apparently only the women is responsible for 
the creating a child? And it's not about morality but about biology. Every 
time you sleep with a women there is a chance you create a new child. And

Both had the right to choose if they sleep with each other or not, sex can

to pay child support for your own kid then don't sleep with women you don't

And also you are moving the goal post. Now we are talking about women that

Both men and women want to have sex but both have to live with the

And lastly you can at least see there is a discussion about this. It's not

example men not having to pay child support at all for their children. 
There is one completely innocent party in this discussion and that is the 
child.

So to call out one feminist because he doesn't take a rather complex stance 
on a complex issue is silly. There is nothing wrong with a movement 
fighting for certain rights from their perspective. Politics is still 
dominated by 90% males after all.

+Dejay Rezme I'm saying that women have more rights than men. Feminists and 
feminist organisations oppose men having any reproductive rights. 
For example it may be appropriate that only the woman should sole right to 
determine if she wants to keep a featus or not. That would seem reasonable 
to me and I imagine most people. However the biological father should have 
a similar right to choose if he should be a father or not. If for example, 
she wants the baby and he doesn't then he should have the right to opt out

have a baby against his wishes, she can't expect him or the government to

Hence men can be granted reproductive rights without removing reproductive

reproductive rights for men because it inevitably means that women have to 
pay the consequences of their choices. 
You are claiming that feminism is about equal rights for both genders. 
However the evidence shows us that this claim is untrue. Perhaps you feel

think that after 40 or 50 years of what feminism is in reality is enough

practices. I just see that most people have identified feminism for what it 
is in practice and hence have abandoned the ideology. 
I think reproductive rights illiterates this quite clearly. It's easy to

don't have then suddenly there are a host of reasons or objections that 
feminists use to oppose it. This Is the very Definition of Hypocrisy.

It seems like your main goal here was to discredit everything she said, 
despite the occasional smoothly thrown in mentions of 'appreciation', 
followed always with a but. But. Even her acknowledgement of men's 
suffering wasn't good enough, because men already know, and she should have 
done extensive research and studies before you can give her credibility on 
her observations. So should she not have brought the issue forwards at all, 
then? Isn't that going back to the starting point? Her speech was refined, 
she said everything she wanted in less than 11 minutes, didn't need to 
recite google to read from to remember her words for backup 
'argumentation', (which in your case, was reading a top list). What exactly 
were you trying to accomplish in this segment besides telling her and your 
audience that her attempts weren't good enough and she wasn't genuine?
I do have to give you credit for your manipulative ability to transform one 
argument into your own and put words into people's mouths ('Men: bad, 
Women: good'... Whenever did she say that?) as if you are psychic and can 
read people's minds. You are king and master of social constructivism. You 
do it so casually, obscuring your own personal observations with facts, 
making it seem like, of course, you're right and know what you are talking 
about. It's astounding. It keeps people at your lips and your presentation 
is very convincing because you are so convinced in yourself. You ease 
people in but your videos always accelerate near the end when you've 
already grasped your wanted audience where you become less careful with 
your words. In this case, for some reason, the topic went from fighting for 
equality to women hitting children. I can recall hundred of feminist 
arguments that ended with statistics of male on female rape, to underline 
their cause. You're doing the same.
In short: you know what it's like to be a woman, and tell them to look 
inside, but they can't observe men and care and acknowledge their suffering 
unless they are occupied with the matter non-stop and studied every single 
aspect, since you dismiss any promise of social change in your favor. For 
what reason, I don't know. Sounds kind of conflicting with everything you 
say about women feeling like the victim. What a conundrum.﻿

+M0oranshi I agree with you that Emma wasn't responsible for pointing out 
in her speech any and all problems that men face. I suspect there is a good 
chance that she *personally* cares about gender equality, but that doesn't 
change the duplicity of the HeForShe campaign or of feminism more broadly. 
For example, Emma brought up that men, like women, are restrained by 
certain gender roles. However, her speech then turned to how freeing men 
from these gender roles would benefit women. Acknowledging that freeing men 
of gender roles *for their own sake* would've been nice, but I give her the 
benefit of the doubt that this was the intended message, albeit a poorly 
phrased one.

Much less forgivable is the lack of real-world action by feminists toward 
improving the plight of men and the language used by HeForShe that is 
similarly dismissive of men's issues. On the first point, what has feminism 
done to address the concerns brought up about (for example) bias in custody 
decisions following divorce? Surely, there are individual feminists who 
care about and have fought this discrimination against men, but it is not 
even a blip on the radar of the feminist movement at large. In fact, Karen 
DeCrow faced rampant criticism from her own ranks for her support of shared 
custody during her time as President of the National Organization for Women.

The same type of hypocrisy is apparent in the HeForShe campaign. It claims 
to be about promoting gender equality, but all of its rhetoric is evidence 
to the contrary. From the HeForShe webpage: "Gender equality is not only a 
women’s issue, it is a human rights issue that requires my participation. I 
commit to take action against all forms of violence and discrimination *faced 
by women and girls.*" But this omission of men and boys must've been a 
simple oversight, right? Not so: "HeForShe is a solidarity movement for 
gender equality that brings together one half of humanity *in support of 
the other half of humanity*, for the benefit of all." For the benefit of 
all? What a crock of shit! When HeForShe (and feminism) admits that men 
face problems in their own right (rather than as side-effects of problems 
that women face) *and* actively work to ameliorate these problems, I will 
take its claim of promoting gender equality seriously.

So glad you point out the language of this speech. 

I suspect Stefan is familiar with covert/persuasive language skills.   So 
much of what we hear is not what is being said.   The primary method of 
this language persuasion is presupposition, which is a statement that 
sounds like one thing is being said, when, in fact, there's an entirely 
different meaning. 

An example.  The question; "Do you think the minimum wage should be 15 
dollars an hour? 10 dollars and hour? Or should it remain what it is? 

Sounds like I'm offering three choices, but in fact, I'm limiting your 
choices.   I'm removing the choice of, "there shouldn't be a minimum wage" 
and directing you to think in terms of there should be a minimum wage.  If 
you select any of the three options presented, you have indirectly said 
there should be a minimum wage, and likely never even consciously noticed 
that the choice was an illusion, and in fact, you were forced into a 
position to accept the idea that a minimum wage is what's best.

Another example; "do you still beat your wife?"   if you answer that 
question, you are admitting that you have or do, beat your wife.

When a salesperson says, "which credit cards would you like to use?" if you 
answer VISA, you have agreed that you are buying whatever is being sold.

These are simple examples, but presuppositions are not always that obvious, 
and they do work to establish a thought.   This speech is loaded with 
examples of presupposition and other persuasive techniques.

In fact, this post I'm making now has some presuppositions contained.  I 
suggest you look for them, and learn how to spot them, because we are under 
a constant barrage of mind manipulation through covert language. ﻿

Masculinity is likely soon to become the new racism, responsible now for 
everything from rape to war.  And, by that, I mean it is likely soon to be 
a viable public view that masculinity is a bad thing. If you challenge it, 
your challenge will be regarded as evidence of your masculinity and hence 
your evil.  All the same sort of BS rhetorical strategies that are used to 
label non-progressive/non-leftist ideas and people as racist, misogynist, 
homophobic, etc., will be applied here. They'll try to confuse the issue by 
identifying masculinity as machismo (which is not always bad and has its 
place, honestly), or just outright violence and aggression.  I think the 
feminists might succeed at this, because I see fewer and fewer men with a 
healthy sense of masculinity.  I see more and more "millennials" who are so 
confused and indoctrinated and so without any principles that they'll just 
bow down like the beta males they are under the pressure. In the vain hope 
of actually contributing to the defense of masculinity, I offer this as 
food for thought. This is my view of masculinity.

Masculinity is the complex of character traits and psychological 
dispositions that result in a man (or any human being) who can effectively 
pursue the goals, aims, or life in general, that he has judged is best, or 
good, or right, preferably with controlled and disciplined emotions and 
feelings that assist him in his pursuit, but also even where his emotions 
and feelings are contrary to his judgments about what is best, or good, or 
right to do.

This view might be summed up more informally as follows. "Shut the fuck up, 
stop whining, and get the job done."

Masculinity is the opposite of the womanish psychology, whether found in a 
woman or a man, whereby one's feelings and emotions are sovereign, 
indulged, and used to gauge or judge social intercourse, personal 
well-being, and even reality on whole.

The idea that is popping up more and more, as in this speech by Emma 
Watson, that men, being men, being masculine, are bereft of emotions and 
hence defective, is inane and stupidly evil shit. Tied to my view of 
masculinity is a rich theory of the emotions, as articulated (with some 
variations) by Plato, Aristotle, and others, according to which, the best 
psychhology to have is one in which your emotions and feelings, in general 
your affective states of consciousness, support or assist your judgments of 
reason about what it is good or right for you to do. Suppose you judge that 
it's an important career aim to achieve X. You want to feel resolution and 
determination. That will assist you in achieving X. You do not want to feel 
fear or timidity pursuing X. That will undermine your ability to achieve 
X.  When you achieve X, you want to feel pride. That emotion will assist 
you in future achievement. You want to feel anger when you've been wronged. 
It will assist you to correct the wrong or avoid it, as you have judged it 
is a bad thing. You want to feel care and tenderness for children. It will 
make you a better father, which you have judged it is good for you to be.

When your emotions are subordinated to your judgments of reason, supposing 
you make reasonably healthy and sound judgments, you will be a more 
effective human being, whether you are male or female. When your emotions 
are out of control and contrary to your judgments of reason, you will be a 
less effective human being and a far more unhappy human being.

That's the ideal. Few will achieve the ideal. As Aristotle has pointed out, 
really, this ideal harmony between the emotions and reason must be 
established, nurtured, and trained from the time you are child. You really 
do need to be trained to have a full set of proper emotional responses 
appropriate to the various circumstances you will find yourself in. For the 
rest of us, we must learn to deal with discordant emotions that undermine 
our judgments of reason about what is best to do.

That's where being a fucking man is most important. In these cases you must 
set aside your discordant, unhelpful, and undermining emotions; you must 
just say to yourself, essentially,"fuck my emotions, fuck my feelings, it's 
time to be a fucking man and get the job done. Period." Being able to 
respond to discordant, unhelpful emotions, so far from being evidence of a 
lack of emotions is evidence of having lots of bad, unhelpful, undermining 
emotions. Being a man, in this case, is just controlling them so they don't 
undermine the pursuit of one's goals and aims.

A lot of women are afraid of this. A lot of women, mostly feminists I 
imagine, want to hold on to their loose, extravagant, chaotic emotional 
lives and yet still obtain the benefits of being a disciplined, controlled 
human being. How will they manage that? By restructuring social and 
political institutions in such a way that the behavior that comes from this 
irrational emotional life is not penalized, and even where possible, it is 
praised and rewarded. The sort of success and achievement that comes from 
self-control and discipline and inner psychological harmony will be 
undermined and devalued in the grand scheme of the "distribution of social 
goods". We are already seeing that transformation now.

The irony of ironies here is that it's the "patriarchical" societies of the 
West that allowed them to live the sort of lives in which they could 
indulge their emotions and feelings so freely and rarely with serious 
consequence.  They'd never get away with that shit in a true matriarchy, 
where women would have to take up serious responsibilities or else the 
society would fold or be destroyed. Yet, today, these feminists not only 
want to hold on to their patriarchical heritage, but they want to scream, 
scratch, and claw for the benefits of being a self-controlled, disciplined 
man in a patriarchy.

sexes in order to change either. Much like spanking is a social practice. 
Interestingly, if you look to much of the internet fight in support of 
spanking, it is coming from the male population. Even more specifically, it 
is being held to religious standard….God, the father, apparently taught us 
to spank our children. (another argument for another time) 

I also noticed that all of your arguments focused on western ideals. That 
it is problematic as this is a UN proposition. You are not taking into 
account the varying rights issues held by men anywhere but (I am assuming) 
the United States. I assume as you mention conscription and here in Canada 
military involvement is not promoted or enforced. The fact of the matter 
is, in many parts of the world, women are treated I would argue, like 
animals. I will not go into detail, as I am sure you are well aware, but I 
also believe that any country (both sexes) should help those who are 
overtly oppressed and brutalized.  I should hope that men would feel the 
same as women in this matter as it is similar to involvement of military 
action; it is often in support of those being in more need of it…I hope.

Now, I did notice some overtly stereotypical and demeaning comments as 
well, regardless of whether they were intended or not. “women are suppose 
to be good listeners – might be time to take that for a spin”, I believe 
was uncalled for, and rude. ( I will not mention your terrible comments 
where mothers are concerned) 

“She appeals to chivalry in he for she, and asks men to man up and be the 
providers and protectors of women, which is exactly what men don’t want 
anymore” I do not agree. As I brought up before, social change cannot be 
made without the involvement of society as a whole. I believe this is also 
what the founders of He for She understand. That being said, what is being 
asked of men is not to stand on the front lines and carry women into social 
freedom. We are not asking men to fight the battle while we stand idly in 
the background. That is a gross assumption, although it is a common 
narrative in male commentary on this topic. What is being asked is simple, 
to stand beside women as an equal member of society. (similarly to you 
arguing men want equity parenting) Just as you explained she did not 
research, or think about male wants and needs, so too are you arguing men 
should not do for women. If neither half of society is willing to 
participate or entertain the ideals of the other then how will either 
gender ever hope to change social ideals? Women know how to create social 
chance on their own, that is proven throughout western history. However, as 
you said, men must be considered. As I said, as men are half of the society 
we are wishing to change. (Although its interesting how males associate 
social activism with a call to war)

I understand your point of her not researching male rights issues, however, 
it must be remembered that this is after all a move towards mainly female 
deals of equality. That is not to say that men’s ideals are not as 
important, it is to say that this is what UN Women are choosing to promote. 
As you said yourself, there are male conferences, and there should be male 
counterparts to discussions and movements of male change based on male 
ideals, however, if no male is going to actually do so, then that point is 
null and void. Just because the majority of the action from this movement 
would be in the benefit of women, and hopefully in majority world 
countries, does not make it a bad one. It is an important humanitarian 
movement that should take place, and with the commentary it had received, 
it is clear to see that many do not agree. This confuses me as I do not 
understand how people can hear about, and see someone wanting to make any 
kind of positive global change, and be reprimanded for it. It seems 
inhumane to me. 

So, we stand in a space where one movement has been proposed, and will need 
all of society, global society, in order to change. However, more than half 
of society is refusing to even consider it as it is tied into a 
historically hurtful ideal. Feminism is responsible for extremist ideals, 
Hence male and female reservations when hearing the word. The name in 
itself presents a gendered binary that is obviously in favor of one sex. 
However Watson stated this. She said, they are searching for a uniting 
word.  But frankly, despite its negative connotations, feminism I believe, 
suits this cause perfectly. It is primarily in favor of helping to 
establish basic female rights in most countries, in hopes of reaching 
gender equality. I believe that if she, in UN Women, were to have used the 
words Gender equality instead, would have received much more criticism in 
the form that you are providing her with. (but what about men’s rights?) 
Again, the name, is a name, and the movement is nothing but positive. 
Therefore this distain for it is entirely unwarranted. Did anyone truly 
expect any one movement to conquer every human right issue? I don’t believe 
that is possible. I believe small battles should be fought and won, and 
more should begin. 

He for She, yes, does literally state that a male is doing something for a 
female. It can also be seen that, having the primary position in a title, 
the man has obviously more respect than the woman in the title. For, mean 
in support of. Not to carry, not to fight for, not to do what she cannot. 
It means that He is supporting she, literally, in her humanitarian efforts, 
and that is not a bad thing. She is not admitting defeat to men; she is not 
admitting inability, when she has proven both already. It is a sign of 
respect in my opinion, to be held prominently in the title. An effort is 
being made to be inviting and being rebuffed on grounds of not being 
respected or invited previously.  But if the only faults you can find in 
the entirety of the proposition are the name, the negative connotation to 
feminism, and a lack of research beyond her male friends. I still do not 
see why you would not support a cause you clearly have no issues with, as 
you have not argued any of its core values or in what it is trying to 
achieve. 

 
I apologize for the length of this rant, I was tired of seeing such 
terrible male and female comments on such a positive proposition and I 
generally truly enjoy your video's. I was let down by this one. ﻿

I posted this on the UN YouTube channel:

Dear Emma,

You claim to want to engage men in the fight for women's rights, which I 
fully support, but then you go on to criticise masculinity altogether, 
suggesting that it is merely brutish and aggressive, and even more 
insulting, that masculinity is the direct cause of domestic abuse. Your 
speech seems to be more about criticising men than it does about ensuring, 
for example, equal pay for women. As a masculine, heterosexual male, I find 
this incredibly offensive. If you criticise violence in relationships, I 
fully support this, having known women who have experienced violence from 
their male partners and having experienced violence myself from a female 
partner. But if you associate aggression exclusively with masculinity, this 
is ill-founded and deeply ignorant. If you criticise masculinity in total, 
you criticise men for being men. That is tantamount to what you call 
'man-hating', whether you would define your beliefs as so or not. 

In one breath you say that feminism has too often become synonymous with 
man hating, and then proceed to criticise men for being masculine, saying 
that it is somehow only the result of peer pressure, as if men do not act 
in a masculine way of their own free will, but are as lemmings, mindless 
copying their peers in an attempt to appear the most masculine. I also find 
this extremely insulting and condescending. I am not unable to express my 
feelings. When I have strong feelings I express them, but I find that many 
men simply do not have the need to express strong feelings, which is often 
a characteristic of maculinity itself. I did not abandon vulnerability and 
it does not make me less human, actually. I do not see that you have the 
right to tell me I am incomplete because I am not overly emotional. You 
suggest that men do this because they are merely conforming to a gender 
stereotype. I suspect they would find this patronising as well. The men I 
am friends with are masculine because that is their nature, and they are 
comfortable with this. I am comfortable with this, and I do not see why I 
should have to change myself by 'getting in touch with my feminine side' in 
order to appear more socially acceptable to you. I am not imprisoned by a 
gender stereotype. You wish to get men on board, then say: well actually, 
the way men behave is wrong and you need to change to be more socially 
acceptable. This is eerily similar to the attitude experienced by many gay 
men, if from the opposite end of the spectrum. 

For the record, I despise terms like 'man up', which I have to say I have 
only ever heard uttered by women in criticism of men who are apparently not 
masculine enough. If there is pressure to be masculine at all, I would say 
it comes from women at least as much if not more so than from other men. I 
would expect a volume of boos if a man stood in the UN and suggested that a 
woman acts feminine because she is told to by beauty magazines - although I 
do acknowledge that the media has a toxic influence on young women, 
something which I cannot say I or anyone I know has ever experienced as a 
man. Who are you to criticise your friends if that is how they perceive 
their femininity? You say that when men are free of the prison of their 
masculinity (which you associate merely with aggression, control and lack 
of sensitivity) then women will be freer as well. I do not understand the 
logic of this at all. Masculinity is not all about aggression and control. 
Gaining more rights for women will not be achieved by attempting to 
eliminate masculinity. I believe you are wrong on both counts. Are you 
suggesting that the way to improve women's lives is for men to stop being 
masculine? I do not accept this and if I feel any oppression at all at this 
moment, it is coming from you.

Far from addressing the perception of feminism, this speech simply raises 
more questions for me. Perhaps you should ask them of yourself. How can you 
speak of equal respect, when you show men nothing but patronising contempt? 
How do you expect to get more men to support your HeForShe campaign when 
you alienate men such as myself with such ill-founded, cynical ideas? How 
can you expect people to look beyond the negative connotations of the word

+limptastic genesis Could you possibly illuminate what in this was 
positive? As asserting it's positive in the face of well put together and 
researched critique which quite accurately and accessibly highlighted the 
glaring contradictions in her logic, as well as the host of faulty premises 
which said logic attempts to build it's house of cards on. The reality is 
not hard to grasp, this speech, was little more than PR theater, attempting 
to soften the brand of feminism, likely in response/reaction to the growing 
MGTOW movement and MRA gaining traction. There was no skeptical 
reexamination of the premises the ideology of feminism is based on, no 
critical re-evaluation of the logic supporting feminism's conclusions and 
policies, only a vague appeal to emotion, and at best an admission of what 
has been glaringly obvious about the movement since it's early rise to 
prominence. Now, if this theater was accompanied by any real substantive 
re-evaluation of feminism, much of the criticism (at least my personal 
criticism) would be moot, or at least mitigated. But, too often this kind 
of feel-good re-branding actually prevents any real self-exploration or 
questioning by those involved, and actually serves to reinforce the current 
attitudes and beliefs, as these kinds of shallow substance-less episodes 
will be held up by the believers as a shield against all those 
uncomfortable contradictions and preconceptions that currently prevent a 
movement supposedly aimed at gender *equality* from even addressing 
inequalities that do not fit their pre-constructed narrative. 

None of this means that women suffer no discrimination or ill-bias, nor 
does it mean that no issue trumpeted by feminism has merit. It merely goes 
to show that, in my opinion feminism has fallen into the same trap as most 
revolutionary ideologies, that of self-reinforcement and an inability to be 
self-critical let alone objective in their assessments and proscriptions, 
as well as the usual refusal to admit and back down from past mistakes.

+Roger McKay Whether you are willing to admit it, or even like it Roger 
everyone is emotional. Every human being; there are preferred "gendered" 
ways in which society expresses their emotion openly (speaking specifically 
of the west) i.e anger in men, sadness in women.

Even though both men and women feel both these same emotions too, the 
processing can be different, but we don't know if that is due to our 
'nature or nurture' as we know socialisation hugely impacts our cognitive 
development.

In decision making emotions play a larger part than most would like to 
admit, especially those who view themselves as 'hyper-masculine'. 

Decision making is largely subconscious, "Common emotional decisions may 
use some logic, but the main driving force is emotion, which either 
overrides logic or uses a pseudo-logic to support emotional choices (this 
is extremely common)". Antonio Damasio

Antonio also found while studying subjects with brain injuries, 
specifically where their were emotions are generated.The interesting thing 
he found was that their ability to make decisions was seriously impaired, 
by the loss of their emotions.

His other studies point to exactly the same thing; 

"research where the subject's brain was wired up to recorders and the 
subject was asked to simply press a red button at any time. The notion was 
that if the conscious mind was in charge, then that part of the brain would 
be seen to change first, an if the decision started in the subconscious, 
then electrical activity in that part of the brain would work first. And 
the answer was...that the subconscious started activity first. As emotions 
also stem from the subconscious, then this makes it even more likely that 
decisions have a strong emotional influence."

The 'men have no emotions, or don't feel emotions the same' trope is tired. 
We all feel emotions the same, some people process emotions differently, 
because of injuries, past trauma, emotional childhood abuse etc but 
emotions aren't gendered and neither is 'rational' decision making. Anger 
is a socially acceptable emotion for men, which is why more men show their 
anger and act upon it. Sadness is a socially acceptable emotion for women, 
which is why more women show their sadness and act upon it.

I love the point about judging a movement not by its extremists but, at 
least partly, by its response to its extremists.  Great point.  As 
for Feminism as a concept, while there are plenty of moderate egalitarian 
Feminists, linguistically the term specifically refers to the promotion and 
the advancement of women above men.

That said, be careful about some of your examples.  The fact that one 
gender may, for whatever reason, outperform the other in a given career is 
not, in and of itself, evidence of an uneven playing field.  Also, the 
horrible imbalance in child support, alimony, and criminal conviction rates 
are greatly based on the assumption of the male-controlled judicial 
system that women are less capable of handling Life on their own, not a 
result of the Feminist agenda.  Beyond that, I got the impression that 
Watson's "bossy" anecdote referred to teachers who called her bossy without 
assigning the same label to similarly minded boys.  As for being "muscly", 
I can only assume that refers to the phenomenon by which TONE is favored in 
the female physique, but MASS is almost universally considered unfeminine.

If you think women don't require the aid of men in the quest for equality, 
then your awareness of historical and current oppression is shockingly 
limited.  Blacks in America would never have won equal rights...or freedom 
from slavery for that matter...without the cooperation of the power-holding 
Whites, and the same is true of the battle for feminine equality.  The fact 
is throughout most of the world, especially in Africa and Asia, male power 
is still absolute.  Don't make the mistake of perceiving that your own, 
safe, socially insulated Western existence is the 
global norm.  Male-enacted laws and the male-dominated religious traditions 
on which they are based are the top tools of feminine oppression.  For most 
women, "What you can achieve, right now, today," is NOTHING!  "The kind of 
protection women have had throughout history," IN AMERICA may demonstrate 
how the world SHOULD BE, but it is by no means indicative of how the world 
IS.  
 
That said, I've worked in law enforcement for over thirteen years, and I 
absolutely agree that, while men are statistically more commonly the 
aggressors, they are by no means ALWAYS the aggressors.  Moreover, one must 
also mitigate any abuse statistics with the fact that many men are too 
ashamed to report their victimization.  Interestingly, the eradication of 
this stigma is a secondary effect of he He For She agenda, allowing men to 
freely admit when they are victims...and hopefully holding female attackers 
equally liable.

As for Watson's brief reference to gender inequality's adverse effect on 
men, the fact that she didn't list specific sources, studies, or statistics 
does not negate the validity of her own direct observations. Like you, I 
generally prefer empirical facts, but political speeches regularly cite 
individual anecdotes to personalize issues.  It's a technique every novice 
debater learns because most people don't "connect with" hard numbers.  For 
that matter, reciting a litany of ways men are hurt would have strayed from 
the primary topic of promoting equality in a world where men still 
predominantly control business, politics, and religion.  Certainly the 
speech was slanted, but you said yourself that it is unheard of for a 
Feminist spokesperson to even acknowledge male victimization, which means 
this speech is a major step in the right direction.  Take the win.

As for Top 10 list... Health: Recent medical research has confirmed that 
each gender is more inherently susceptible to certain DIFFERENT illnesses, 
a "discovery" due to the fact that more women are working in the medical 
profession than previous generations allowed.  It's not that women's health 
is receiving the lion's share of focus; it's that women's health is finally 
receiving a more equal share.  Education: ADD & ADHD over-diagnosis 
(particularly of boys) is a modern, LAZY, liability-wary reaction to the 
way Evolution has conditioned juvenile males (of most species) to play and 
learn...and that reaction is CRAP!!!  Reproductive Rights: Absolutely 
RIGHT, except for one thing.  To claim it's "perfectly acceptable" for a 
woman to have an abortion is a gross misstatement of popular opinion.  Even 
where it's legal, abortion still comes with significant social stigma.  As 
for the perception by the masses that ALL men are inherently rapists and 
abusers, this is the first time I've ever heard such a statement, so the 
perception can't possibly be that widespread, except among man-hating 
Feminist extremists.  Anti-Male Double Standards: Absolutely no argument.  
In fact, I'd submit that "affirmative action" programs that give 
preferential treatment to women are exactly such an animal.

While I agree that corporal punishment is universally over-used, my law 
enforcement experience has consistently demonstrated that 
homes without REASONABLE physical aversion conditioning (spanking) more 
often produce adults without respect for authority, boundaries, rules, or 
consequences.  It's true that abuse often begets abuse, but drawing a 
direct link between adult violence and childhood spanking is like saying, 
"Most drug addicts were fed milk as children, so milk is a gateway 
drug."  If exposure to corporal punishment created a propensity for adult 
violence, then your statement that most men have no desire to 
victimize women would be inaccurate because most men were spanked as 
children.  For that matter, since most of the world's women were also 
spanked (or worse) as children, violent crime rates SHOULD be equal for 
both genders all around the world, BUT THEY AREN'T!  Most of the worlds 
most productive and peaceful citizens, both male and female, were spanked, 
and they turned out just fine.  To neglect this fact is a disingenuous 
insult to victims of real violence.

By the way, it stands to reason that women statistically hit their children 
more than men because men are usually less involved in raising the 
children, including disciplinary action.  It saddens me that someone whose 
research I generally respect would present a statistic so out of context.﻿

+renger6002 I do think it sounds like we have the same ethical fundamentals 
with regard to this topic. Where my opinion in the details differs from 
what you've said above though is that I do not think that feminism is 
inconsistent with men's rights (though I recognise it is inconsistent with 
the MRM which if google serves me, is by definition explicitly against 
feminism). And I also do not think that feminism itself claims to have any 
sole right to fighting gender inequality. Because, absolutely - even though 
sexism cuts both ways and so men would still benefit - since the movement 
tends to have a largely female voice for a female cause, it is likely that 
many men's issues may not be highlighted. So a 'brother' organisation which 
highlights men's rights is in my opinion, extremely appropriate. And if 
both are at the fundamental level movements for equality, then they can 
only be considered to aid one another, not undercut or work against each 
other. The very idea of women not having agency is an insulting one in this 
society because of the level of power women in the western world do have. 
And so the burden of responsibility men are upset about is also a 
discomfort to women in it's own patronizing way. Imbalance may hurt each 
differently but it hurts both all the same. My understanding of the speech 
was not "men, you are invited to help women directly, to the exclusion of 
helping men directly" but rather, "men, you are invited to help women 
directly because this will help men too" with the unsaid (I recognise I am 
adding this in, but this is my assumption due to the movement being one 
resting on the pillars of equality), "and women, you too are invited to 
fight directly for men's rights, because this will help women too".  So I 
think the "help yourself by helping women" was simply an acknowledgement of 
the natural side effects of inequality on gendered individuals. And my 
understanding of patriarchy being central in feminism is less of a "men are 
bad" but a "we come from a place where power was placed in the hands of 
predominantly males and this has impacted our views, our language and our 
human dynamics - let's try and name and deconstruct this given this 
history".

I guess in some ways I am calling for a type of overhaul. But the thing is 
it isn't as dramatic as of feminism itself, because there are many 
feminists and feminist groups who remain firmly and consistently in the 
idea of equality as the definition of the movement. But I guess I am hoping 
that when "feminist" groups (angry or political propaganda or bought by big 
business/ special interest groups or just plain sexist) do something that 
does not adhere to the very definition of equality - then we all stand up 
and call it out it for not being representative of the movement, and thus 
name it as fraudulant and inconsistent. 

So for example (and I hope I don't cause bad blood with this part) - the 
idea that abortion is in line with the view of feminists is one that 
appears to have been influenced and pushed politically through special 
interests and all sorts of messiness (incidentally primarily by men - not 
that it matters,  I only mention that to highlight the false advertising). 
The original feminists were against the idea, and felt it to be a power 
issue whereby the individual (foetus) with lesser power is devalued. So now 
there are feminist movements naming this and saying - hang on - that's 
inconsistent.

It has indeed been lovely conversing with you, and refreshing to engage a 
topic thoughtfully without constant name calling :)

+Skyturnip This is an example of inequality cutting both ways. So yes, when 
women are disempowered and are considered weak and incapable then men 
suffer too. That is why the goal is an equal society. Because inequality 
hurts us all even if it is in different ways.

+Ray Ealdwine "Is there dispute about whether we come from a patriarchy?" 
What does that even mean?

Do you mean the patriachy that sent millions of men to their deaths in WWI, 
yet not a single women died on the WWI battlefields? I'd happily give away 
my vote (which is meaningless anyway) for a draft exclusion in WWI.

+Ray Ealdwine I agree that It does intuitively make sense that we have come 
from a patriarchal past, and I would agree with you that we definitely do 
not live in a world where it holds as much sway as it used to. Let me say 
that it sounds like we are saying the exact same thing, a world where you 
can have different groups being activists for different targets, which 
makes perfect sense. What I was talking about was the rendition of the 
patriarchal theory as it stands in the current form of feminism which seems 
to (correct me if I'm wrong, and I mean that genuinely) hold the position 
that whether you want to fight for men or women, you must do it under the 
umbrella of feminism, since in order to make men's lives better, the 
patriarchy must be destroyed. This makes perfect sense if you hold the view 
of the full force of agency belonging to men, but it seems to me that women 
in this day and age have access to agency should they choose to grasp it. 
Instead we have a speech by a supposed spokesperson for feminism (who 
actually didn't even bring up very important women's issues in her speech 
in my opinion), asking men to stand up for women, under the guise of 
helping themselves. As if signing up for that movement will do away with 
any of men's issues. I have no problem with the campaign, and I find the 
speech fairly harmless, but disingenuous. I would have much rather 
preferred, "let's help women", instead of "help yourself by helping women".

Is there dispute about whether we come from a patriarchy? That's a genuine 
question, I'm not being aggressive. This seemed a given to me due to women 
having no right to vote, no claim to the throne as a daughter, no allowance 
to work, and men were known as the masters of the households etc. and so 
women by nature as not having the education, skill or right to support 
themselves, became the dependent and less empowered sex. I am not 
suggesting it is like this today in the western world. But that is where we 
have come from and so remnants of the system may still be in place (like 
taking one's husband's surname - language matters, language implies things 
about power), if not in law, then in narratives and norms. And since time 
has passed, men's rights issues may also have grown and become very real in 
this time. There are always people in the world (no matter what they call 
themselves) who try to overstep the boundaries of the other - and so when 
this happens, outcry is appropriate.  In some parts of the world the power 
discrepancy is still very stark with women having little power. And 
sometimes that is due to them physically having less power/ strength. Am I 
saying that men are bad abusers? No. I am saying that there are norms are 
narratives in the world that still use violence as the end point. So 
stronger on weaker, be that male, female, child or animal. I am digressing 
but my point is only that power dynamics matter. And feminism has been a 
voice that historically has named the dynamics that hurt women. Now I would 
argue that since feminism is built of the fundamental striving for 
equality, any notion put forth in the name of feminism that does not, 
should be rejected as part of the movement. And I think this is what emma 
was trying to do. To reclaim something brave and important. For if we all 
stand up against sexism - through feminism and the MRM, and we name and 
reject that which is sexist and does not adhere to the core principles - 
i.e. if a feminist group is being sexist then they are not a feminist 
group. Well then we are taking back something which means a lot, and can do 
a lot of good for everyone.

I'm not saying you shouldn't ever be critical and just always accept things 
naively. I think it is very important to have your own thoughts and your 
own brain and to view the world critically, so I understand that different 
opinions being voiced about Emma Watson's Un Speech, is only natural and 
necessary.
However, the arguments you bring seem both a little bit forced and 
prejudiced. Emma Watson makes it a very important point in her speech, that 
it is not about the word "feminism" - it is about the idea that the 
dictionary claims it to be. So even if "the reality" shows that a lot of 
feminist acts are actually anti-men, it still means that the word 
"feminism" has the same definition as before - the idea of gender equality. 
And this is what she fights for. Gender equality. She is aware that 
man-hating is a reality, and clearly wants to change both that, and the 
gender inequality towards women, which is exactly why she even points it 
out and then continues to define the word. She wants to separate herself 
from the unfair man-hating part of feminism.
You also show confusion, when the girls leaving their sports teams were 
mentioned, because according to you, "muscly women" are displayed as 
desirable in the media. First of all, this was not always the case. I'm 
only 21, but, just as an example, I remember my Barbies having no muscle, 
but (unnatural of course) curves instead. Yes, recently "fit, toned women" 
have been advertised a lot, but this is still the very slender kind of 
"muscly". Emma Watson only mentions her girl friends not wanting to be 
"muscly". I'm guessing she means the sort of muscles that aren't perfect 
and toned and visible because of almost no fat covering it, but rather the 
kind of muscles that are just gained as a "side effect" to exercising, 
which aren't toned but just larger and bulkier than normal ones. This is a 
whole different kind of "muscly". Also; if it was their reality that 
appearing "muscly" made them feel unwanted and unattractive by other 
people, it was exactly that. Their reality. Could Emma Watson have 
explained this with more detail? Probably. Her way of keeping the sentences 
short and specific, with few powerful adjectives, obviously made the speech 
gripping and interesting and it made a whole lot of people listen.
Your point on how her message is women NEEDING men to stop gender equality, 
and even that men are always bad and women always the victims is just not 
correct. She makes it such a clear point that both men and women face 
gender inequalities that I am surprised you missed it. Not once, does she 
say that "only men are bad" or even that men "must be involved". Not once, 
does she say that "women are always the victims". She doesn't even mention 
domestic violence, which you bring up on your own. To me, it is obvious 
that violence, sexual assault and gender inequality is a reality for all 
the genders. To some people it might not be, so for that reason I can see 
your point in bringing it up. But exactly this is Emma Watson's point in 
her speech. Let us change ALL gender inequality, which then of course also 
means: let us change the perception that only men can be violent to women, 
and never the other way around.
She invites men to join the feminist movement, which right now consists of 
mostly women. Her point is that society in general focuses way too much on 
what a man should be and what a woman should be. And not at all who's fault 
it is or isn't. I think it is true, that if we invite the men to join the 
very women-based movement, we would have a lot more success, because as she 
says, how can we change the world, if only half of it is invited?
You also make it a point, that feminists never actually fight for equality 
but just for women's advantages, and that a "true" feminist by definition 
would fight for, for example men having the same job opportunities as women 
in higher education. First, and most important of all: just because you 
haven't met one, how do you know they don't exist, and how do you know that 
Emma Watson isn't one? As mentioned before, she clearly states, not being 
of the man-hating kind. Second of all: as with the domestic violence 
subject: this topic also, is not the real point and essence of this speech 
which you are analyzing. Third of all: some jobs and areas are largely 
occupied by men and some are largely occupied by women. They just are.
You also mention her choice of voicing the gender inequalities that men 
face, by talking about personal experience. These are examples. It often 
makes something feel more real when something feels personal. People can 
identify with Emma Watson's experiences, better than plain statistics. And 
quite frankly, she hits them pretty spot on. As you mentioned yourself, one 
of the biggest problems men have with gender binding roles, is them being 
the strong, providing, fear-and emotionless one. Which is exactly what she 
mentions. She can't name every single one, as she can't with every single 
inequality issue women face.
You keep mentioning mens' rights and that men are pushed to save women from 
inequality. Again. Exactly her point. BOTH men and women experience gender 
inequality.
You say, it is obvious she hasn't spent time researching what men want and 
need. I say it's obvious she has. And while the campaign is called He for 
She, which is supposed to raise awareness amongst men as well as women, it 
is NOT a campaign directed ONLY to men. Even if she neglected YOUR needs or 
MENS' NEEDS, do we really have to get something to give? Do you have to get 
your issues solved, before you want to help women's issues. Again, not the 
point of the speech. Let's try uniting instead. For a man who dislikes 
feminists who man-hate so much, you seem quite women-hating (or at least 
generalizing them A LOT) yourself.
The speech very obviously reached a lot of people, and I believe that is 
because Emma Watson is a young woman, a lot of people look up to (in my 
opinion for good reason!), who is very talented and kind, and 
wholeheartedly tries her best to make the world a better world for 
everyone. And because she wrote and held a brilliant speech. It was 
relevant, very relatable, realistic but positive, short but precise and not 
to slow and not too fast.
As you felt free to lecture Emma Watson on giving a speech to men, I feel 
free to say to you: you are doing quite a poor job at appealing to women. 
You seem condescending, arrogant, presumptuous, you generalize and a lot of 
your points are, yes very important, but irrelevant to the speech and it's 
message.﻿

thought "she can't hurt me anymore"  unexpectedly roared into my head.

civilized. I look like (and am) a physically big, emotionally tough guy but 
the beatings and violence, anger I experienced as a kid affect me to this

not helpless but there are parts of me that my mom's violence damaged 
beyond repair. It's been like trying to grow a new arm out of an amputated 
stump. It ain't happnin'.

Dear Stefan Molyneux,
I absolutely understand and agree with you defending men's rights, however, 
please take time to review what you said and try to listen to it from the 
perspective of a woman. It sounds as if you are excusing the crimes against 
women by bringing into light the crimes against men. I am sure that you did 
not intend to do so but it certainly sounds like that. The truth is that no 
crime, committed against men OR women is excused or diminished by a "worse 
crime". All crimes should be punished and considered as such. I agree with 
you that men are often punished harshly and that there are women excused 
from crimes or judged "softly" when they should not. We are all HUMAN. 
Everything that we do should count as a HUMAN ACT. Not a woman's act or a 
man's act. A crime is a crime and no one can be excused just because they 
are a woman or a man OR because someone else committed another crime. 
Again, I agree with you that a lot has to change in the legal approach to 
crime in general and that false accusations should be perceived and judged 
as a most serious and horrendous crime.
The thing is, as I mentioned earlier: your post does not promote equal 
responsibility either. I get where you're coming from but how can any of 
us, HUMANS, change ANYTHING in this equality matter if we only judge it 
from one point of view. How can we "better" things if when the subject 
comes up it all turns into a bloody gender war for 'The most wronged one'. 
As I read the comments to this video I became more and more confused, 
angered and sad to see that NO kind of understanding was being achieved. I 
saw only hate, from both men AND women.
What you say about the beating of children and the empowerment of women 
does TRULY HAVE to be spoken of. However, you turned to an offensive 
lecture to women. Yes it is true that many many many women spank their 
children. It is also true that this is ultimately and irrevocably WRONG. 
Yes I agree with you that violence comes from violence and that if you 
perpetrate it then it will spread but you have to see that this is not the 
only issue. You cannot or should not be seen as an accuser of women to be 
the only guilty party in perpetrating violence. Sadly your speech gives 
that impression. 
I want and need to say that I, as a woman, am not on 'the women's side' or 
'the men's side' of this discussion. I decided to write this for you as a 
HUMAN on 'THE HUMAN'S SIDE' because, for me this is the only side that 
should be taken and so often is not in many more discussions other than the 
gender equality one.
As to what concerns the #HeforShe  movement I believe that it as been 
misunderstood. Emma Watson left out important issues that should have been 
spoken of as you said but she was not trying to drag men into the 
'protector part'. As I understood it, what she was trying to say is that 
the Feminist movement should be involving men NOT to act as women's 
protector or to defend them as if they couldn't do it for themselves. I 
believe the intension behind #HeforShe  is to INCLUDE men into the fight 
for gender equality, for COMPLETE gender equality in favor of men and 
women, WITHOUT diminishing the injustices committed against both genders in 
favor of one of them. What stood out for me was that it doesn't treat men 
as the enemy but as a part of the whole that needs to be in sync with the 
other part in order to actually make a better and just change. There are a 
lot of things that need yet to be included into the discussion, yes that is 
true, so maybe instead of turning AGAINST one another we could JOIN each 
other to have a more CLEAR AND COMPLETE perspective.
I hope I didn't seem condemning because that is not my point and should 
never be anyone's (although condemnation is a part of our human nature it 
is not correct, at least in my eyes, and we should try as much as we can to 
avoid it). I needed to write this as a hate free constructive comment which 
I felt was truly needed.
There is so much more to be said, I hope that in the future there is room 
to internationally discuss all of it, of what needs to change. This was my 
try out at understanding and freeing myself of prejudice I hope I achieved 
it.﻿

formalised instruction (the sort of thing we associate with more complex 
forms of adult organisation). It is said that a good leader leads by 
example. Whilst there is undoubtedly a large grain of truth to this, it 
appears to be of only tangential relevance in today's adult institutions 
when it comes to setting, enacting, and running policy, whilst it can and 
perhaps should be the driving ethos of hierarchies among younger people.

belong.

boys shouldn’t be equally addressed.  The feminist sexism of the HeForShe 
campaign creates two classes of citizens: those who are important enough to 
be protected (women and girls), and those who are left to themselves (men 
and boys), without explicit protection from organizations or governments. 
They are implicitly, or “de facto”, considering men and boys as second 
class citizens.  How did we end up accepting such extreme sexism from these 
women?  Aren’t there any women (or men) who also care about their sons, or 
the men of their lives (or men as a group)?  This campaign shows again that 
societies (and especially some sexist, feminist-women) care less about men 
than women, and even more monstrous, that they care less about boys than 
girls.
 
There can’t be a gender equality without having a movement that also 
include the liberation of men. How can we pretend seeking gender equality 
when we are not even able to say that sending men to wars or to a military 
service was, and still is, a sexism against MEN?  Or if we hide that 
“child-soldiers” are in fact “boy-soldiers”, as if we were unable, as a 
society, to admit that this is a problem affecting almost exclusively boys 
(shame on us).  When we listen to a feminist-women, we can see that she has 
no empathy toward men (she only speaks about women and girls), especially 
when they speak about the “African women”: we can see their total lack of 
solidarity toward the “African men” (…and boys!).  These women should be 
ashamed of their misandry, and if they are not, ALL women should be ashamed 
that they pretend to speak in their name.  Emma Watson should be ashamed of 
this accepted misandry which is building up in the society, because of 
campaigns like HeForShe.  In the USA, Hillary Clinton should be ashamed of 
being one of the strongest advocate for this feminist sexism. Women must 
evolve too, they must learn that showing only solidarity and empathy toward 
their own gender IS a form of sexism from their part, and they should be 
ashamed of what these sexist, feminist women are doing on issues affecting 
men (they are preventing liberation of men).  They must learn to show 
solidarity and empathy toward their “opposite gender” (like men do), at 
least as much as they are toward their own.
 
Traditionally, men have the role of protecting “women and children”, and 
this constitute a sexism in itself (against men), because woman should also 
pay the price for “protecting the nation”, and they should not receive more 
protection (from men or societies) than men.  What the HeForShe campaign is 
asking is to perpetuate this sexist expectation that some women have toward 
men: they want men (… and boys!) to protect “women and girls”.  By the way, 
notice that we passed from the concept of protecting “women and children” 
to protecting “women and girls” (boys are of the wrong gender I suppose): 
do you consider this as “gender equality”, Emma Watson?
 
We don’t live in a world where only women are oppressed, and where only men 
have privileges: women, societies, also have sexist expectations towards 
men, and women also have privileges (… one of them being the solidarity and 
empathy we show towards women and girls, but not towards men and boys, as 
demonstrated by this HeForShe campaign).  A few decades ago, sexism and 
issues affecting women were not recognized, and we see the same phenomenon 
with the sexism and issues affecting men: we don’t recognize this 
particular sexism (we didn’t learn).
 
Issues affecting men and boys must be equally addressed: men and sometimes 
boys are forced into “slavery” with military services or conscriptions (for 
example, we must force nations to stop this sexism and force mandatory 
military service or conscriptions for women too, if they are not ready to 
eliminate it).  Men occupy dangerous jobs which leads to overrepresentation 
in job related deaths and health issues.  In demonstrations, men are far 
more likely to be targeted for violence or killing, and they are more 
likely to be massacred in wars or genocides.  A man’s life expectancy is 
shorter than a woman’s life expectancy, and we close our eyes on the sexism 
leading to this imbalance.  Same thing with the education problems 
affecting boys (because of the incompatibility between education and the 
traditional role they are destined to), which is not addressed the same way 
they are addressed when discrimination is affecting girls.
 
As we can see at the UN and other organizations sites, when they use the 
expression “women and children” (which exclude men), they are in fact 
promoting discrimination against men by only considering the mother-child 
link, to the expense of the father-child link (as if the mother-child link 
was more important): that’s pure sexism against men.  And this, despite the 
fact that men is the gender which is discriminated against when it comes to 
child cares (considered not compatible with men’s traditional roles).  The 
UN, instead of fighting against this woman’s privilege, is perpetuating it, 
and has the indecency to call this gender equality.
 
We see this same sexist double standard in regards to genital mutilations 
(GM), which is treated differently depending on the gender of the victim.  
GM made on girls is considered a crime, while GM made on boys is not (and 
we invent all sorts of to excuse to justify this double standard, or 
sexism).
 
This feminist sexism has created a new privileged group: women and girls, 
because the violence and discrimination affecting them are being addressed, 
while the violence and discrimination affecting men and boys are not being 
addressed.  Men and women must fight against the sexism of this “HeForShe” 
campaign, because gender equality is not about caring only for women and 
girls, it is not about protecting women and girls only, it’s about fighting 
all kind of sexism, including the sexist expectations of societies (and 
women) toward men… and including this “neo” sexism introduced by the 
feminist ideology.
 
I think we can only achieve gender equality by developing a new 
“anti-feminist” progressive movement, which would fight for both men’s and 
women’s rights: for a real gender equality.  On the contrary, if we 
continue to only show solidarity toward women and girls (= feminist 
sexism), we will antagonize and polarize societies that we want to change, 
and movements fighting for human rights will continue to lose ground to 
more conservative values (because they are not fair, bring injustices and 
double standards affecting men and boys).
